text:
Here we are on Zoom,
first time, for our second or our penultimate session
of the academic year

and an opportunity to
learn from Laura Huang about her incredible research
and her recent book, Edge:

Turning Adversity
into Advantage. Many of you have had the
pleasure of meeting Laura.

She's been at HBS since
2018 as the MBA Class of 1954 Associate
Professor of Business

Administration in the
organization's behavior unit. And her research interests
are really fascinating,

because she's been studying
these subtle signals and cues that often impact
perceptions of investors.

And so leading to, how do
people choose who to invest in?

And how do we make sure
that our voices are heard and that our advantage
is put forward?

And I must admit,
it is very surreal sitting in front of
my computer screen, especially with the Stamps
Reading Room background,

when I know this isn't
where I really am. But my heart is really there.

Usually, I like to be standing
outside the Aldrich classroom door and welcoming you.

So this seems very odd. But on the other
hand, it's enabling

us to get together in
a way that we wouldn't have been able to otherwise. So Laura, we'll dive in.

And Laura's asked us to try to
be as interactive as possible. She's going to talk us through
some portions of the book,

some things that
resonate with her, especially with
everything that's

going on with the pandemic. And then we'll just
open it up to questions.

But just one norm is it
would be helpful to all of us if you could type out your
questions so that we have

them running in chat, as well. And then when we get to a point
when you want to make a comment

or ask a question,
just raise your hand, and then we'll turn
the mic over to you. So Laura thank you so
much for joining us.

We're looking forward to hearing
about how to have an edge. Thanks, Deb. Hello, everybody.

Hello, hello, hello. Thank you to all of you
who have your videos on. I love seeing faces here instead
of seeing boxes with names.

So as many as you who are
willing to, please turn

your videos on. I would love this to
be really interactive. Even though we're in this
very, very surreal environment,

I see some of my
students out there. I see some alumni. I see some colleagues.

It's so amazing to
be able to do this. So thank you for
experimenting with us on this.

I was telling a
friend of mine today-- I was saying, well, I get to
be the first to give a book

talk over Zoom. So there are silver
linings to this.

The book that I wrote that
was released on January 28

is called Edge: Turning
Adversity into Advantage. And when I wrote
this book, I was not

thinking about adversity
particularly in this way. I was not thinking about
all of the different nuances

that we would be dealing with
in this current environment. And in some ways, I
almost feel like the book

should have been titled,
turning your adversity into your advantage, because
what I sort of realized

is that this pandemic, this
virus, these circumstances that we're in right now,
it's really impacting people

so differently. And one of the things that I
talk a lot about in my book is that this is really
something that's personal.

When you think about adversity,
there are broad things

that we think about. There is adversity based on
someone's race, or gender,

or class, or circumstances. But there's so many
nuances involved, and there's so
many different ways

that people have to handle it. And one of the things that
I'm realizing his that we all

had our own routines,
our own ways of going about the day, our own ways
of dealing with something

like this. And so the solution also
needs to be something really individual, as well.

The book I wrote was really
about how some people naturally have an advantage in
life and others have

to create one for themselves. And it's based on
this notion that we're

taught from a really
young age that success is about hard work. You ask super successful
people, you ask leaders,

you ask our graduates,
you ask people who have won
Olympic medals, what was the secret to your success?

And inevitably, people
will mention hard work. It'll be one of those
things that they mention.

And we recently, I think in
the last couple of years, have had this love affair
with hard work and grit.

And if you put in
that hard work, the accomplishments, and the
outcomes, and the rewards will come to you.

But in the back of
our minds, we also know that even though
hard work is critical,

hard work alone isn't enough. There is definitely
this dimension

to we put it in the
hard work, and hard work leaves us frustrated.

And that's because so much
of the outcomes and success in our lives are due to things
like signals, and perceptions,

and the stereotypes of others. And so this book
was really about how we can flip the stereotypes
and obstacles in our favor

so that we can find and
create our own edge. And as I think about the
journey, even the things

that we're faced
with now, it's really about doing the same things
over, and over, and over again,

and hitting the same walls
over, and over, and over again. And I think even now, one
of the frustrations we have

is that we came into this
with a lot of momentum. All of us were sort of going
along with the momentum

that we had been expecting. And then it was like
we flipped a switch, and we're still expected to
do all the things that we were

doing before in the same
ways to the same extent,

and yet, we're not quite
able to step back and say

that we need to be able to think
about things in different ways.

There was an entrepreneur
that I was just talking to the other
day that was saying, last month, I brought
in $15,000 in revenue,

and so far this month,
I brought in $0. And it can't be,
how do I go back

this new reality,
this new normal, how do I now tackle
those sorts of things?

And I think those are
some of the things that I talk about in the book,
albeit not towards coronavirus

itself, but it's
how do we empower ourselves to use the tools that
we have to create our own edge?

And so the book-- even though it's about
how do you gain an edge, it's based on this framework
that I've developed through

more than a decade of my
research, where the E-D-G-E-- the EDGE-- actually
stands for the components

of this framework. The E is for Enrich. It's about, how do
you enrich and provide

value in any sort of
context that you're in? It's about, how do you
think about your abilities,

and your strengths,
and your underestimated strengths and weaknesses,
and how do you

take those to really
provide value to any context that you're in?

The D is for delight, because
a lot of times, before we even have the opportunity
to enrich, we

realize that we're either
not given that opportunity because we don't belong
to the right networks,

or the right groups, or
because we look a certain way, or we, for whatever reason,
don't have that chance.

And so when you're able to
delight someone, when you're able to delight,
that's the equivalent

of being able to crack
that door open so that you get that opportunity to show how
you enrich and provide value.

The G is for Guide,
because even when we enrich, and
know how we enrich, and are able to
delight others, we

need to be able to guide
the perceptions of others. We need to be able to redirect
them to who we authentically

are and guide that
narrative around who we are and the trajectory that we have.

And that final E
stands for Effort-- effort and hard work. We often think that
effort and hard work

comes first, that if you
put in the hard work, that the rewards
will come to you, that hard work will
speak for itself.

And the hard work
comes lost because when you know how you enrich,
and delight, and guide,

that's when your hard
work works harder for you. That's when you're able
to take those headwinds

and those tailwinds,
and your hard work becomes hard work plus. That hard work works
harder for you.

And so in our
current environment, in terms of facing this
adversity, whatever

form it comes in, however
it's impacting us, however it's impacting
us differently,

one of the important
things is being able to go back to thinking
about how we enrich,

going back to our basic
goods, going back to, what are those three or four
core things that really make us

who we are? And understanding, then,
how we use that to see and act upon these new
opportunities to delight,

how we can hone
our ability to see how this affects us and
enables us specifically to continue to guide these
perceptions in this new reality

that we're in. So I want to stop
there because I don't want to make
this a true book talk,

in the sense that
I'm presenting slides and I'm giving a
[INAUDIBLE] keynote,

but more having this
be this interactive way

that we approach this. So I would love to
hear what thoughts

you have on what I've said so
far, any reflections you have,

and make this very
conversational. And questions or reflections
that you have at this point,

I would be happy to in
turn give my thoughts on. So anyone who has any
reflections, please

feel free to either raise
your hand using the Hand Raise feature or type in your
comments to us here.

And I'll just pause for a
second to allow us to do that.
It's not usually a shy bunch. I think this goes to--

I do see a hand. I'm just going to
give a quick comment and then we'll get to
Kendall and Nicole.

But one of the reflections
I had in this environment also is that what I write
about and a lot of my research,

it's about these nuances. It's about these
perceptions that we have. It's about the fact that
you can walk into a room,

and you change one variable,
and everything changes.

You change the industry
that you're in, or you change the mix of
people that you're with,

or you change the time
of day or the context, and everything changes, which is
why it's so important to really

be able to hone
your gut feel around how you're being perceived
in your interactions with other people.

And this dynamic that we're in
makes that even more apparent. To some extent, we are
losing a lot of signals

that we were
ordinarily getting-- body language, the
way in which somebody walks across the room,
the way in which they

approach you and introduce
themselves to you. But at the same
time, I think we're becoming much more apparent.

We're focused a lot more
on facial expressions. We're focused a lot more
on other different dynamics

and different ways in
which we have to interact. And I think that's
something really important

as we acknowledge this. One of the things that I
do a lot of research on is uncertainty.

How do we make decisions under
conditions of uncertainty? And what makes it
especially complex now

is that normally, under
conditions of uncertainty,

we do things like try and put
together contingency plans,

measure the risk,
try to make decisions under probabilistic outcomes.

Here, we just don't
have a lot of that. We are under extreme
risks, in the sense that we don't know if this
is going to last for a month

or if this is going
to last for a year. We also do things when
we're under conditions of uncertainty, like
we follow others.

We do what others are doing. We use others as
sources of information. But in this situation,
that's not necessarily

the best thing, either. And so what a lot
of my research has looked at in the
past couple of years is in what instances do we
want to be relying on data?

In what instances do we want
to be relying on our gut feel, on our intuition? And how do we know
the difference?

Because there are
situations in which we do want to rely on our mental
models, and our schemas, and our intuition, and chuck
out the analytical information.

But in other instances,
it's the complete opposite. So this makes it
particularly challenging

to really gain our
edge because we're dealing with this
contextual reality, as well

as the new reality that we,
ourselves, are placed under. So I've now talked
sufficiently long for there

to be lots of hand raises
and lots of comments.
And so let's start with Kendall.
Is Kendall in video? I don't know if she is.  Oh, I see. OK. So would you please--

any reflections or questions
that you might have? Yes. I think I'm looking
through the chat and I think it
relates a bit to--

No, don't copy
those from the chat because you had your
hand raised first. No, I think there's
overlap with Caroline's.

My question was,
basically looking back at your own research
and your path

to even decide to enter the
field and pursue this career, how have you seen the
EDGE framework play out?

In your own decision-making,
how has that led you to where you are today?

And those different
components you're describing--

what are, perhaps, examples of
those in your research work? Yeah.

So I've been studying
inequality, and disadvantaged,

and people who
were underestimated for quite a long time. And one of the
reasons why I started studying this in
the first place was

because before I even
went into academia, I remember as a child that I
was growing up, and my parents--

I would see them getting
passed over for promotion, after promotion,
after promotion, both my mother and my father.

And I remember that in
one particular instance, my dad had gotten passed
over for this promotion

that he really, really wanted,
and that he really, really thought that he
deserved that, and he had put in a lot of hard work.

And when he was denied that
promotion, I asked him. I said, well, why do you
think it was that you

didn't get this promotion? And this was at a point
where he was still doing the job of his boss, who
had gotten promoted over him.

So the person who got
promoted over him was actually not qualified to do it,
but was doing this job.

And so I said, why
do you think it was that you didn't get this? And he said, I don't know.

It's probably
because of my accent, or because of the way I
communicate, or something

along those lines. And so when I went
into academia,

one of the very first things
that I started studying was accents. I ran a series of studies where
I wanted to find out, indeed,

were there differences
based on someone's accent? And I found through
multiple studies

that people were less
likely to get promoted, they were less likely to get
hired for top management team

positions, they were less
likely to get funding-- all sorts of negative outcomes
based on their accent.

I tested whether it was
because of communication, and I would randomly
assigned people

who had native American accents
and non-native American accents to different conditions
and would do things,

for example, where
I'd have investors not rate whether or not they
would invest, but give me

three bullet points of what
you remember from this person's pitch. Or what are three things that
you learned from this person's

presentation? And what I found was that
there was no difference. In fact, those who had
an accent were actually

able to communicate
more, in some instances, and investors were
able to learn more from those who had an
accent than otherwise.

And so I was like, OK, if
it's not about communication, what is it about? And found that there's always
these underlying perceptions,

that we know we can't
discriminate against people for things like accent, for
example, but we can agree like,

OK, we're going to
hire someone that can think outside the box, that
is a good team player, that

is interpersonally influential. And it just so happened
that those characteristics

were what people with accents
were rated the lowest based on. There were these
underlying perceptions.

And so what I then did, and
the impetus for this book, was I kept finding these
negative outcomes based

on not just accent, but
things like gender, and race, and class, and age, and
ethnicity, and religion,

and sexual orientation--
all sorts of things. And I kept getting asked
the question, well, what do we do about this?

Are there ways that we can
then level the playing field? And so what I've been doing
the last couple of years is trying to find
ways to inoculate

against these sort of things. How do we flip
things in our favor? When we know that
there's stereotypes,

how do we flip those
stereotypes around so that they work as an advantage,
rather than as a negative?

And so when I recognized
that there were underlying perceptions-- that people
with accents, for example,

were getting rated much lower
on things like interpersonal influence or being
a team player--

what I then did was I would
have those individuals go into interview situations. And before they did,
I would say to them,

the perception
they have about you is that you're not as
interpersonally influential,

or the perception that
they have about you is that you're not a team
player, that you're not as good in teams.

And so they would go
into these situations and they would get asked
the normal questions that we get asked.

Things like, tell me
about a time when-- and they would respond
by telling about a time,

for example, where they fought
for resources for their team, and they were
interpersonally influential,

or they didn't stop until
they closed that deal. And what I found then was that
not only were they rated higher

on things like
interpersonal influence, they were also rated
higher in terms of things like
communication, and they

were more likely to get
promoted, more likely to get that raise, more likely to
get the financing all based

on addressing and flipping
that negative perception that they had about
them in their favor.

I'll give one other
quick example of this. In some of my
research on ageism,

we tend to assume that people
who are older employees-- the lay perception is
things like they're not

as good at technology,
they're not as technologically proficient, things like that. But I found that there's
an underlying perception,

and that underlying perception
boils down to one thing, and that's curiosity.

They think that older
employees are not as curious. So when I send those older
employees into a job interview,

for example, and I
say, the perception that I have about you is
that they're not as curious,

so they go in and they
start asking questions. And they start giving responses
to those interviewers.

They say things like,
I'm curious about how your vision has
evolved over time,

or I'm curious
about your strategy, or I'm curious about
your competitors. They're not only rated
higher in terms of curiosity,

they're rated higher in terms
of technological proficiency, in terms of a whole
host of other things,

and they're more likely
then to get that job. And so that's what I mean
by guiding and redirecting

those perceptions. When you're able to understand
those underlying beliefs

and attributions that
others have of you-- and that's a whole other
segment of my book, when

I talk about how do you
hone your ability to see those underlying perceptions. But when you're able
to do that, that's

when you able to guide, and
redirect, and really flip things in your favor. So I know that's a longer
answer than I normally

would give to a
[INAUDIBLE] question, but in the spirit of this
talk and interactional

thing, that was great, Kendall. Thank you for kicking us
off with that question and that observation.

Lots of other hands that I
see now, so this is great. Nicole, can we go to you next?

Yes. Hi. Thank you so much
for [INAUDIBLE].. Hi. This is awesome. My question is about
whether you think

there are specific mindsets that
allow people to better utilize the EDGE approach, and so how
we can start to cultivate that

within ourselves,
and with daily ways that we can try and
practice incorporating this.

Absolutely. OK, so that's great. So number one, there is
a quiz on my website.

If you go to my
website, laurahuang.net, there is a quiz
that you can take that speaks exactly to that.

So it's called the EDGE
Quotient or the EDGE Quiz, that based on my research,
I've taken questions

that you can answer
that then tell you, how equipped are you
to find your EDGE? Which dimension, which areas
do you need to be honing more?

And then I also have
a practical guide, which has strategies
and different ways that you can figure out for
yourself how to do this.

I'll give you one example of
a strategy, or a tactic, or a how to when I talk about honing
this and thinking about this.

So there's an exercise that I
used to do with my students, and I used to do a number
of experiential exercises

with them to hone this ability
to develop their own gut feel

or develop their way of
understanding how others see them and the attributions
and the perceptions

that others are
making about them. But one example of this is
called the 10 No's exercise.

And what I would
have my students do is over the course of a
week, their assignment

was to get 10 people
to say no to them. And they could do it over any
medium-- over email, in person,

over the phone-- but it had to be a no. It couldn't be a hedge. It couldn't be like, oh,
well, I'll do this instead.

If you get that, you
have to start all over. And they had to write one
paragraph about each of the 10

no's, each of these
no's that they got. And then in class the next
week, they had to present one

of these no's. So what this did
was it emphasized

and it showed students
in this very real way that we were so used to getting
people to say yes to us.

The muscle we've been
developing our entire lives is trying to influence
people, and trying

to get people to like us, to
say yes to us, to agree with us.

But with the
assignment, in order to complete this assignment,
they had to get people to say no to them.

They started realizing
that they communicate with different people
in different ways.

They show people different
sides of themselves. They show different
dimensions of themselves

to different people. And when they need to try to
get to a no instead of a yes, they're realizing
that they then start

to communicate in different
ways using different language, and it starts to build this
new way of understanding

how other people see them. They realize, number
one, that people are a lot less willing to
say no to you than you think.

People also are much
more willing to say yes than you think. It also shows you the way
in which you communicate

to different people
and the reactions that different people have
to you in different ways.

I say to some to do
some of my students, especially recently, students
that were having trouble

getting into class, having
trouble raising their hands,

and getting into
the conversation, and trying to hone this. I had a couple of students
that I would say this to.

I didn't say this to
all of my students because that would then just
get totally out of control. But the students who
came to me and said,

I'm really having trouble
communicating in class, and knowing how others
react to my comment,

and whether a comment is a
good one or not, I would say, you know what? This week, what I want you to do
is just give something factual.

When you raise your hand,
communicate something factual-- a case fact or something
that adds to the discussion
in a factual way. And see how people respond. See how your professor responds.

See what other students
say in response. And then next week,
what I want you to do is I want you to listen to
what other people are saying

and I want you to agree with
what somebody is saying, but add one dimension that
we haven't considered.

And see what the reaction
is in different classes, and different topics,
different parts of this.

And then the week
after that, I want you to agree with
what they're saying, but then add one dimension
that we haven't considered

that maybe disagrees or has
some sort of different nuance. And what you're
really doing is you're

A/B testing for yourself
the different reactions, the different perceptions,
the different attributions

others have of you. And so when you do exercises
like the 10 No's exercise or you do something
like this, it

helps you learn about
those perceptions that others are having.

It helps you learn about
how you should react and the ways in
which you're reacting that might be more positively
inclined, more negatively

inclined, and all
of this threads to hone your ability to do this.

And Nicole, the other
thing I want to say to this is the other thing I write about
in the book is that everyone can learn how to do this, but
not everyone is willing to.

And what I mean by
this is not everyone is willing to put themselves
out there and fail in this way.

Get those 10 no's. Be OK with that. Put yourself out there and allow
yourself to be embarrassed.

People are a lot more
willing to have failure

sometimes than they
are to be embarrassed. We get embarrassed and
then we say, never again.

Never again will I put
myself in that situation. When you feel embarrassed,
there's so much data in that.

There's so much data in why
you should be doubling down, putting yourself in another
situation where you're

embarrassed in that same way or
embarrassed in a different way, but similar. There's so much information
in why does that still

continue to nag at me? Why does that still
continue to bother me when it wouldn't in
some other circumstance

or why someone else wouldn't be? When you start to
get those, that's when you start to hone
those sorts of things.

And so in the book,
I talk about lots of different practical
exercises and different ways to think about that.

So thank you for that question.  Deb, I'm going to let you
lead this because now there's

so many in the chat room. OK. And also, Gwen has
her hands up, so I'm going to let you start
calling on people

so that this is done in
a more organized fashion than what I'm able to do.

Great. Great. Well, why don't we go to
Gwen, and let us know -- what's your question?

Well, it's kind of
unfair because I did put my question at
the bottom of the list and a lot of people
are ahead of me.

But I'll just say it-- That's OK. You can double-dip, Gwen. If you raise your hand and
you write your question,

there you go. You've already found your
way to get an edge in there. OK. So my edge.

But it is on all of our behalf. My question was,
how can we use EDGE thinking to get a woman
elected president?

[LAUGHS] OK, so there's
so many different ways

that I can answer this. So the question is, how
do we use this to get

a woman elected president? So I've done a lot of research
that's looked at gender, and has looked at
perceptions and attributions.

And the thing about
gender, there's

a large tradition
of research, there's decades and decades
of research that has looked at this trade-off
between warmth and competence.

We have these stereotypical,
gender-type stereotypes

that we expect certain
people to act a certain way,

behave in certain ways. And so I think what
happens a lot of times

is that when there's
not a congruence between these male type
and female type stereotypes

in what we're seeing, that
that congruence really leads to some of these outcomes.

So let me be more
specific because I'm being kind of abstract in this case.

In some of my research,
I find that when we picture what an
entrepreneur looks like,

when we close our eyes and we
have people try and picture an entrepreneur, we picture
some dude in a garage.

People who are doing
tech-based startups.

Maybe he's a college
dropout from Stanford,

but he's a coder. We have these views of
what a successful prototype

of an entrepreneur looks like. When we then have women pitching
a technical startup that's

high growth, high scale,
it just doesn't fit. And so there's a
number of things

that happen there when there's
this lack of congruence. Number one is that we start
asking that female entrepreneur

lots of questions in order
to test their credibility,

or test their legitimacy, test
their technical competence. We also have expectations
around how warm and competent

that person should be. I found in some of my
research, for example, we're more likely
to ask women what

are called prevention-focused
questions, questions around competition,
technical details

in order to try and figure
out whether that person can fit the stereotype or fit this
prototypical entrepreneur.

We're more likely, on the
other hand, to ask men what are called
promotion-focused questions, questions about the opportunity,
how big something can get,

the vision. And so part of
this EDGE thinking is around
acknowledging that this

is a reality, that
there are stereotypes, and that we're going to be led
by some of these stereotypes

and be influenced by
these stereotypes. But then also knowing
how we can turn that

around to create
a different norm, a different way of thinking.

So there's one
chapter in my book where I literally
insult everyone. If you are not insulted,
then I haven't done my job.

I go through the stereotypes
of every single person-- of women, people of
color, people who are old,

people who are female
and a person of color and old, like all of the
different intersectionality,

all of the different countries,
races, religions, classes,

what those stereotypes are. And what we need to
do is acknowledge that 80% of those perceptions
that others have about us

are going to be based
on those stereotypes. But then there's that 20%
that we can flip in our favor.

And so this EDGE thinking
is about redirecting that, redirecting in a
way where we can still

be congruent with what those
expectations are, but then exceed those expectations
in other ways.

And so the example I

I did the opposite and
went to the early ones, and there's several that have
kind of all come together

when people are asking,
how do you keep all of these things top of mind?

If you think about you're
in the middle of a pitch, and you've got all the

and then you've got to remember,
oh, I've got the perception and I have to do all this,
how do you pull all of that

together? You don't. You don't try and keep
all of these in your mind. This is the thing.

We tend to overprepare
all the time. It's great to be prepared,
but we overprepare.

And what happens is we go
into meetings sometimes, especially when we feel like
the odds are against us,

or when we feel like
somebody disagrees with us and we need to
convince them, we often

do things like we
have our six bullet points of ways in which,
as soon as we give them,

they're such great points. We're going to make
this point, and then that counterpart, that other
person is going to be like,

yeah. You know what? You're totally right. I agree with you now. That never happens. But what happens is we
have those six bullet

points in our mind and we go
in and we go on super strong, presenting all of
these different points

when that's the worst thing
that we should be doing. Instead, we should have maybe
two or three vague notions

of the titles, rather than all
of the subtitles, these larger

things, because when we
have those points in, we become rigid. We start to have
this conversation

and are completely always
trying to redirect it to these amazing points that
we have instead of going

in and having this
more loose way so that we can improvise
and delight in the situation

that we're in. We want to be able to
meet people where we are, and toggle, and
improvise, and to do

all of these sorts of things. We need to be able to also
tailor it to who we are

and the opportunities
that we see. So I'll give you
an example of this.

When I started my

of the associate deans.

how do I do that? I was this brand

And I was like,
how do I do that? And they said, well, obviously,
you just invite them to dinner.

Invite them to lunch. Have meals with them. Have drinks with them. And you don't even
need to have an agenda.

You just want to
get to know them. And so this was the
advice that I was given. And so I started
emailing people,

and I knew enough to know
that I couldn't invite them to dinner or drinks.

I knew enough that that
wasn't going to work for me. But I, instead, was like, OK,
let me invite them to lunch.

And so I was having lunch
a couple weeks later with this senior associate dean.

And he was like, OK, so what
do you want to talk about? And I was like, oh, I
don't have an agenda.

I just wanted to
get to know you. And all of a sudden, he
looked really almost annoyed

to be inviting him to lunch,

there should be a

like the state of the

And where's the agenda? But for my male

And so the lunch was disastrous. I made such a horrible
impression on him,

and I was thinking, I'm
never going to do that again. And then a couple weeks
later, I was on a flight.

And I was giving a talk
at this conference. And this senior associate dean
was on the same flight as me.

And I saw him, and I
was like, oh, my gosh. Please hide because
I don't think

I can ever have a conversation
with this man again. And he saw me, and at the end
of the flight, he was like, oh,

hey. Hi. Do you remember me? And I'm like, oh, yeah. Of course I remember you. And he's like, are you
going to this conference?

And it turns out he was
going to the same conferences that I was going to. And he said, so how are you
getting to the conference

hotel? Which was about 45 minutes
away from this airport. And I said, oh, I don't know. I'm probably going to
get a taxi or something.

And he's like, oh, well I
have my private car waiting. Do you want a ride?

And I was like, oh, well, I've
got my private car, as well, which is a private taxi cab. But he's like, no, no, no.

Come join me. And so I joined him. And in this 45 minute ride
from the airport to the hotel,

it was no longer in
someone else's way.

I had an opportunity
to get to know him where there didn't need to be
an agenda, where there were

no expectations, and we were
able to just talk and chat, and he got to know me. And this is, again,
one of the people who

has remained in
my life as someone that I go to, that
is very influential,

I've been able to
maintain a connection with for a really long time. What we don't realize
is that when we say,

how do we keep all of this
at the top of our mind, that what we sometimes are
asking for is this recipe

or what are the five things that
I need to do to get my EDGE?

So many people

take to get an advantage or to gain my EDGE?

I wish there were these five
steps that I could tell you. [INAUDIBLE] very, very personal,
and the more personal you

make it, the more authentic it's

And they say, oh, well, first,
I went to business school, then I did a rotation in

I can guarantee you, if you
follow that exact same path, you will not get to
that exact same position

because you are a
different person and you have a different set

So the best that I can
present is this framework for thinking about, how do you

And how does your effort
go further for you? But really, it's not about
keeping these in your mind.

And if I can say one other thing

give this advice to people. We say, just be yourself.

and we tell them,
just be yourself. Or I'm giving this
big presentation. Oh, they're going to love you.

Just be yourself. Or you're going on a

horrible advice.

Be yourself is horrible
advice, and not for the reasons why you think I'm going to say.

It's horrible advice because
there is no yourself. There are your selves.

There are so many different
versions of who you are. We are a complicated
and varied people.

And when you say,
be yourself, that doesn't really provide
us with any information.

I often talk about
it, each individual-- if you think about each
person as a solitary diamond,

and based on that
diamond, you're going to shine differently
based on the lighting,

the environmental
conditions, based on the cuts of
the diamond, based

on the angles at which
you're looking at, based on who is
looking at it, based on

that you can turn
that diamond and it's going to shine brightly
and shine less brightly.

We are a diamond with flaws,
and facets, and different cuts. And when you're go and you're
interacting with somebody, what

you're really doing, what
you want to be doing, is showing that
angle of your diamond that's going to
shine the brightest.

That's where you're going to
be able to have that richest, deepest connection with someone.

This is not strategic. This is not managing
impressions. This is showing them
that side of you

that is going to shine the
brightest so that you can have that connection and
you can continue

to delight them, and guide them,
and show them how you enrich.

Yeah. This whole process actually
has been terrifying. It really has.

And I'll tell you
it's been terrifying. I have been doing research
for a really long time.

And my research is out there. It's like numbers, and
statistics, and findings,

and it's aggregate findings. And so when I started getting
asked the question, well,

what do we do about this? I had never really
intended to write a book.

Research is the thing
that I've been doing. But I kept getting
asked this question,

like what do we do about
all of these disparities that we're seeing? What do we do about
the disadvantages what

do we do about the fact that
we are working hard and not always getting the
benefits of that

or seeing the
success behind that? And what I recognized was that
a lot of the academic findings,

a lot of the research was
around these structural things that we can do. Things like we need
more women mentors,

or we need more women who
are in executive positions, for example.

And all of that is great. None of that is going to hurt. But at the same time,
it doesn't help us

as an individual to
empower ourselves as we're are waiting
for the system to change

or the system may change in
ways that we don't intend, creating other issues. Or maybe they're
going to change,

but more slowly or in different
ways than we expected. And so I really wanted
to write a book that

was around how we, individually,
could empower ourselves, even within a system that is
either imperfect, or imperfect

and not changing. Even as it's changing, we
don't need to wait around

for it to change. There's things that
we can do ourselves. But in order to do that, it
did have to be very personal.

And so when I was writing
the book, the first draft, I just was trying to get 80,000
words down, to be honest.

I was just trying to get
80,000 words down on paper. And so when I did that, I

figuring that there would be
a really long editing process, that we would edit
this, and there was.

We went through this three
to four-month process of editing it.

But when I finally got the final

from a true reader's, rather

I was like, oh, my gosh.
This story is still in there? That didn't get edited out? Or this didn't?

And so that's what I
mean by terrifying. It was all these
really personal things

where it felt like people were
going to be reading things that it made me feel much more

there's some examples there
